CHILD ABUSE IN HCMC: There are still local districts and counties being dishonest in their reports

To address the rising issue of child abuse, a monitoring team has been assigned to assess the situation among local authority entities in HCMC. The assessment identified the following problems: 

1) Numbers of child abuse cases reported are not consistent to what the monitoring team has witnessed previously.
2) Numerous cases still goes unreported from the family and many of these cases involved close family members as the abusers.
3) Local authority is not fully equipped to handle the cases appropriately.
4) There are gaps within the legal procedures to protect children which need to be filled.

We think that these findings are not novel. However, the report has brought attention to the issue in an evidence-based manner with detailed recommendations. Such information can be beneficial to various child protection entities in their mission to create positive impacts. Our club hope to hear more about your thoughts below!

Our representatives from the Ho Chi Minh City Club of Social Workers (CLB CTXH) as well as several experienced souls from NPOs/NGOs providing support for the community with disabilities (including DRD, CED, Thien An Shelter, and Asia Rainbow) had the opportunity to meet and exchange conversations with a UNICEF Specialist, Ms. Marianne Schulze today. The meeting provided crucial information for the current advocacy research effort, coordinated jointly by UNICEF Vietnam and the National Committee for People with Disabilities. Information gathered from the advocacy research will be used to review the situation and establish recommendations to revise as well as improve the law in the near future.

CALL FOR PROPOSAL:
 
The UN Trust Fund to End Violence against Women is accepting applications for its 21st grant cycle (2017). Civil society organizations are invited to submit grant proposals for a minimum of US$50,000 up to a maximum of US$1 million for a period of three years.
 
Proposals are invited under the following three programmatic areas: (1) Improving access for women and girls to essential, safe and adequate multi-sectoral services to end violence against women and girls; (2) Increasing effectiveness of legislation, policies, national action plans and accountability systems to prevent and end violence against women and girls; and (3) Improving prevention of violence against women and girls through changes in knowledge, attitudes and practices.
 
This year, the UN Trust Fund is also seeking applications that specifically focus on:
 
(a) addressing violence against women and girls in the context of the current forced displacement and refugee crisis; or
 
(b) addressing violence against women and girls with disabilities.
 
Applications from womenâ€™s rights, women-led, and small womenâ€™s organizations are prioritized, in recognition of them being the driving force of the ending violence against women agenda, as well as being at the forefront of reaching women and girls survivors at the grassroots level.
 
The complete Call for Proposals detailing criteria, eligibility requirements, and application guidelines is available at: http://grants.unwomen.org/ or via the UN Trust Fund homepage.
 
The application deadline is 5 December 2017.

 Project and Administration Assistant (Loreto Kids Charity)

1. Loreto Kids Charity
Loreto Kids Charity (formerly known as Loreto Vietnam Australia program (LVAP) is a registered international non-government organization (INGO) in Vietnam (Permit Number: 15/CNV-VPDA) dedicated to the reduction of poverty through beneficial, qualitative and responsive educational opportunities for underprivileged and disabled students. Since 1997, LVAP has reached out to over 60,000 children through our projects; giving them support in various forms to foster an encouraging learning environment. Our staff are comprised of a dedicated, small team based in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.
2. Position 
The Project and Administration Assistant is responsible for the general office reception responsibilities and administrative support to both the Office and Finance Administrator and the Project Manager.
3. Major Responsibilities 
Administration responsibilities:
- Being initial contact point for the office inquiries and communication.
- Providing translation and interpreting as required.
- Being responsible for office related procurement and services.
- Managing the office petty cash and preparing small cash payments.
- Checking the detailed breakdown of payment request items from partners and agencies, and following-up as required. 
- Maintaining office filing of documentation and record updates.
- Providing administrative support to the running of the office, including service related issues, printing, maintenance, and other ad-hoc tasks as required. 
- Reporting to the Office and Finance Administrator regarding work plans and completed of project tas
Project responsibilities:
- Assisting in the monitoring of projects to ensure appropriate progress on implementation of project plans: issues, risks, impacts and assessments.
- Assisting in organizing and taking part in project/ field visits to monitor project progress.
- Implementing purchasing process related to project activities 
- Drafting and/or translating project related documents, where required 
- Assisting in the coordination and implementation of short term projects including bicycle and school pack distributions, excursions, exchanges, fairs, exhibitions.
- Providing support to the Project Manager and team regarding longer term project implementation. 
- Assisting with project related filing and data input. 
- Coordinating gifts in kind received and donation boxes.
- Reporting to the Project Manager regarding work plans and completed of project tasks.
- Supporting with volunteers as required.
- Undertaking other tasks to support team members as and when required.
4. Requirements and qualifications
4.1 Essential
- A University degree. 
- Excellent written and spoken English and Vietnamese language skills.
- A minimum of 2 years practical administrative experience, and project support .
- Ability to analyse information, evaluate options and to work strategically
- Excellent interpersonal, communication and presentation skills and ability to work effectively in a team.
- Demonstrated IT skills 
- Demonstrated writing and presentation skills (official letters, minutes, reports)
- Ability to be flexible and respond professionally within different contexts.
- Demonstrated organizational skills and ability to respond to tight timeframes or deadlines.
4.2 Desirable
- Experience within the INGO context and in working with provincial, district partners, and/or local communities 
- Experience with the production of printed and online communication.
- Experience in financial management and reporting.
- There are occasional work and travel obligations associated with the work of Loreto and this position that may include weekends and/ or evenings as required.
5. Submission details

Further details regarding Loreto Kids Charity can be found at www.loretovietnam.org.

Dear Social Work Colleague,

We hope that you will join us for this year's Social Work Summer Institute. The Institute will offer free social work and community health workshops from May 22nd to June 7th at An Giang University in Long Xuyen, An Giang Province and this year for the first time from June 19th to June 23rd at Open University in Ho Chi Minh City, an endeavor made possible by the commitment of West Virginia University, An Giang University, and Pacific Links Foundation. Come learn and share your experience with us. Registrations are due May 17.

We invite participants who are social workers/collaborators/counterparts of international and local NGOs, staff, faculty, and social work students from university setting.

The focus for this year's Institute will be on:

Workshop 1: Solution Focused Therapy: Re-Solving Problems through Exceptions (Map 22 â€“ 23)
Workshop 2: Prevention, Awareness, and Capacity Building (PAC): Addressing Gender Inequality, Sexual Exploitation, and Human Trafficking (May 24)
Workshop 3: My Home is the Street: Working with Street Youth (May 26 â€“ 25)
Workshop 4: Social Psychology for Social Workers: The Psychology of Social Injustice & Prejudice (May 29 â€“ 31)
Workshop 5: Working with Drug Abusing Clients: The Basics of What You Need to Know (June 1 â€“ 2)
Workshop 6: Meeting the Longer-Term Mental Health & Psychosocial Needs of Trafficked Women (June 5 â€“ 7)
Workshop 7: Solution Focused Therapy: Re-Solving Problems through Exceptions (June 19 â€“ 21)
Workshop 8: Working with Drug Abusing Clients: The Basics of What You Need to Know (June 22 â€“  23)

Updated workshop schedule and more details can be found at http://pacificlinks.org/events/socialworkinstitute/.

The European Institute of Cooperation and Development (IECD) is a French non-governmental organization founded in 1988 and operating in the field of social and economic development in partnership with local institutions in the countries where it has been involved. 
IECD bases its actions on a comprehensive approach to a person. We do this as we believe that well educated people, on an academic, technical, social and human level, will build not only a better community for themselves and their family, but also for their community and for society as a whole. IECD encourages the youth, parents, professionals and locally-based development actors to play a responsible and active civic role.
IECDâ€™s main sectors of action are vocational training and professional integration, assistance to micro and small enterprises and access to education and health for the most vulnerable. In Vietnam IECD runs 4 projects: Support to Small and Micro enterprises with a specific focus on street vendors, 2 Social Training Enterprises in Bakery and Pastry based in HCMC and Hue and a Vocational Training Program in Electricity and Automotive.

Today UNESCO released its Global Education Monitoring Report entitled Education for people and planet: Creating sustainable futures for all. This report reflects on progress since 2015 when 160 governments came to an agreement (the Incheon Declaration for Education 2030) aiming to ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning for all by 2030. UNESCO initiated this report, building from prior Education for All reports, to provide independent monitoring and reporting of the Sustainable Development Goal on education for the next 15 years, to ultimately leave no one behind.
 
Why does this matter?  Besides being directly relevant to our mission, we currently use statistics from UNESCOâ€™s reports for our public materials.  I am sharing key links and statistics below and will be reviewing our 2016 messaging materials (saved here) and updating any necessary statistics by September 15. Please also review your personal materials and make any necessary statistical adjustments.

Key report statistics & highlights:
Â·         Over 2005â€“2014, some 758 million or 15% of adults globally lacked functional literacy skills; 63% of whom are women. [Note that Room to Read has used â€œnearly 800 millionâ€ when possible to avoid inaccuracies with this number as it tends to fluctuate.]
Â·         25 million children do not even begin primary school.
Â·         Almost 30% of children from the poorest households in low-income countries have never been to school.
Â·         If low-income countries were to reach their target of universal upper secondary education by 2030, then by 2050, per capita earnings would increase by 75% and the percent of people living in poverty would significantly decline, thereby lifting 60 million people out of poverty.
Â·         39% fewer workers from poorer backgrounds would be in low paying informal work and in working poverty if they attained the same education level as workers from richer backgrounds.
Â·         In low-income countries, only 67% made it to the last grade of primary education.
Â·         If women achieved universal upper secondary education by 2030 in sub-Saharan Africa, it would prevent 3.5 million child deaths in the decade beginning in 2050.
Â·         The world is set to achieve universal upper secondary school completion half a century late.  Southern Asia is behind the global average, estimated to achieve universal upper secondary completion in 2084. Sub-Saharan Africa falls behind that, estimated to achieve the target at the end of the century.
Â·         While Sub-Saharan Africa reports gender parity of those who have completed primary education among the richest 20%, among the poorest 20% just 83 females per 100 males completed primary education. This disparity widens to 73 females for lower secondary and 40 for upper secondary.

Applications are invited for the Many Languages, One World 2016 Student Essay Contest for the 2016 entry. The United Nations Academic Impact One World, Many Languages Essay Contest is open to students 18 years and older enrolled in a full-time course at university.
60 Students will be selected as delegates to the 2016 United Nations Academic Impact Global Youth Forum, 25-31 July, 2016, where they will create action plans related to the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The students will present these action plans at United Nations Headquarters in New York City.
Airfare, Room and Meals will be provided by ELS Educational Services, Inc. at Hofstra University.
Share your ideas and be heardâ€¦ perhaps even in the General Assembly Hall of the United Nations!
How to Apply
Write an original essay (2,000 words or less) discussing global citizenship and cultural understanding and the role that multilingual ability can play in fostering these. The essay should reflect your personal, academic, cultural and national context.
Essays must be written in an official language of the United Nations that is not your first language or primary language of instruction during your primary or secondary education.
The official United Nations languages are Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish. You will need to demonstrate both written and verbal competency in the language of the essay.
You must be a full-time university student, recommended and endorsed by a Faculty Member or University Representative, and must be 18 years of age or older by the contest deadline.
Essay Submission Deadline: Thursday, 31 March, 2016 at 11:59pm Eastern Standard Time (EST)
Entry Process
Write your essay according to the contest rules and eligibility guidelines.
Share your essay with the University Faculty Member or Authorized Representative who recommended you so that s/he can attest to the fact that you have followed the contest rules.
Have that Faculty Member or University Administrator complete the Faculty Member/University Administrator Reference Form in support of your participation in the contest.
After the Faculty Reference form is submitted, the Faculty Member will receive an email from Many Languages, One World requesting confirmation of the reference.
Make sure that your Faculty member looks for this email and clicks on the confirmation link. They may need to check their spam or junk mail folder. If your Faculty member does not confirm their recommendation, you will not be able to submit an entry.
Once the Reference Form has been received and confirmed by Many Languages, One World, you will receive an email with further information, and a link where you can complete your Student Entry Form and upload your essay to the contest website.
The Student Entry Form must be completed in its entirety, and in English. If your entry form is incomplete, you will be disqualified. Be sure to include your government-issued identity card number or passport number, and submit your full name as it appears on your official documents or passport. Do not submit your photo.
At the bottom of the Student Entry form you will find the link to upload your essay to the contest website.
The essay must be submitted/uploaded in MS WORD format. Please title your essay as follows: LastName_FirstName-LanguageofEssay (ie, Smith_Jane-Arabic). Do not include a cover page with personal information, as the essays will be evaluated anonymously.
Only essays submitted through this link will be accepted. You can only submit one essay.
Essays must be received by 11:59pm Eastern Standard Time on Thursday 31 March, 2016 in order to qualify. Do not wait until the deadline date to submit. Give yourself time to ensure that your essay will be received successfully.
Please Note: If the contest directors learn that you have violated any of the rules, or that you have neglected to cite sources, or have used any translation service or software to write your essay, you will be immediately disqualified.

Dear Sir/Madam,
It is with great pleasure that the Consulate General of Canada in Ho Chi Minh City, in cooperation with the Gender and Society Research Centre of Hoa Sen University, would like to invite your organisation to participate in a first-ever celebration of International Day of the Girl Child in HCMC on Thursday October 8th  between 09:30 and 11:30 at Hoa Sen University.
 
International Day of the Girl Child was established - as a result of a joint initiative by Plan Canada and the Government of Canada - by a resolution of the United Nations General Assembly in December 2011 with the objective of recognising the unique challenges faced by girls around the world, with the first day being celebrated on October 11th 2012.

We expect to structure the event in two parts, with the first featuring short presentations by a number of adolescent girls on the challenges they have faced and on their experiences of empowerment, with the second being built around a panel discussion by a small number of experts, followed by a Q&A and networking session.
 
We are therefore inviting interested non-profits and others to:
 
Â·        nominate a girl speaker for the event
Â·        recommend a panelist to speak about issues facing adolescent girls
Â·        indicate their interest in attending the event
 
We would welcome and encourage your participation in this event (by reply to dung.vu@international.gc.ca), which we hope will be the first of many celebrations of the Day in the years to come.

Dear colleagues and friends,
 
The PROPEL project (Promote Rights and Opportunities for Persons with disabilities â€“ Employment through Legislation) would like to invite you to apply for the Training of Facilitator (TOF) â€“ Disability and Equality (DET) in Hochiminh city from 28th September â€“ 02nd  October, 2015.
 
What is DET and why is ILO involved?
 
Disability Equality Training (DET), as promoted and practiced by ILO, is a group-work approach to changing attitudes and practices towards the greater inclusion of persons with disabilities in mainstream services and activities. It is linked closely to the social model of disability. As well as being challenging and informative, this form of DET aims to:
-         Sensitise participants to the implications of disability issues, and the experience of disability and impairment, for the service they plan, run, support and promote.

-         Introduce participants to the basic tools and concepts they need in order to make the changes necessary to ensure equal participation in those services by persons with disabilities.

-         Stimulate actual and meaningful change in participantâ€™s day-to-day work and lives.

ILOâ€™s way of delivering DET is effective because its dynamic and participatory methodology respects and builds on participantsâ€™ existing experience. The ILO has used DET since 2008 to promote disability inclusion among parliamentarians, national and international civil servants, government and ministerial officials, employers, trade unions, leader of DPOs and many more.
 
Who can participate in an ILO TOF â€“DET?
 
At present, ILO TOF-DET programmes are available only in English. The programmes are highly participatory, so candidates must have a good level of proficiency in understanding, speaking and writing English. Candidates must also have prior experience of facilitation or training. Experience of facilitation or delivering training to professionals or decision-makers will be an advantage.
 
There are only 8-12 participants on each five-day TOF-DET programme, so that each participant can receive personal attention!
 
ILO provides reasonable accommodations to enable suitably-qualified persons with disabilities to participate in the TOF-DET. Unfortunately, at the present the TOF-DET is not available for sign language users.
 
Who is Mater Trainer?
 
Ms. Maureen Gilbert â€“ is Disability and equality consultant with broad experience of working in Ireland, US, UK, Africa and Asia for UN, statutory bodies and NGOs.  Ms. Maureen has strong writing and editorial skills, particularly in the production of toolkits, practical guidance and policy documents. She also is skilled facilitator and researcher with good evaluation and policy development capabilities. She has extraordinary experience in mainstreaming of disability inclusion in design and systems including disability proofing, devising and delivering disability equality training (DET), and conducting related training of trainers. 
 
Please send this application with a short CV to Ms. Tran Quynh Trang (quynhtrang@ilo.org) by September 07th 2015. Applications received after this date will not be considered.

INTRODUCTION
WVVâ€™s Area Development Programs (ADPs) focus within one administrative district of a province which usually populated by ethnic minority people with very high rates of poverty. ADPs are mainly funded by sponsorship funds, and are a phased approach to development, involving clear and consistent assessment, design, and implementing, reporting, monitoring and evaluation and reflection phases. Each ADP is tailored to the needs of a specific community in alignment with WVVâ€™s strategic priorities. WVV works closely with district and commune local authorities and local partners to implement program activities. A uniqueness of WVVâ€™s ADP approach and structure is that team members are based at district level where the ADP is located, which enables them to work closely with government partners and communities on a daily basis.
The current ADP structure is based on sectoral approach with one staff in charge of one sectoral project. Since FY11, WVV have applied the Development Program Approach and revised its ADP structure. Under each ADP, there are from 6 to 8 staff, including 1 ADP manager, 1 Sponsorship Facilitator, 1 Finance Officer/Bookkeeper, 1 ADP Coordinator and 2-4 Development Facilitators (DFs) who are in charge of all projects and programme activities for around 2 assigned communes/wards in their ADP (from assessment to planning, implementation, monitoring, evaluation and transition). For each cluster (3-5 ADPs), there are 4 technical cluster staff: Health/ WASAN/ HIV/AIDS; Education; Agriculture/ Economic Development; DME/Capacity Building. DFs will be coached by the ADP Manager programmatically and by the technical cluster staff technically. One of the strengths of this structure is to allow better integration of the program toward Child Well-being Outcomes.

Please circulate within your networks.  Open to staff & board.
Deadline:  June 1, 2015 (but an extension, if necessary, is certainly possible)
 
Are you a community foundation or grantmaking professional?

want to increase strategic philanthropy in your local community?
seek networking opportunities with Third-sector colleagues worldwide?
aspire to lead the community philanthropy sector in new directions?
 
If youâ€™ve answered yes to the bove, apply now to the
Emerging Leaders International Fellows Program

This is a professional development opportunity for emerging Third-Sector practitioners to support community philanthropy and help build local grantmaking capacity in their home countries.  
Fellows will
participate in small group seminars and discussions with leading practitioners in the philanthropy/foundation community.
visit community foundations and other grantmaking organizations in the field to learn about their day-to-day workings.

join a network of 198 alumni from 63 countries.

produce a research paper reflecting new strategies.

International Fellows Program: Spreading the Seeds of Community Giving.
 
About the Center on Philanthropy and Civil Society (www.philanthropy.org)
Founded in September 1986, the Center's mission is to strengthen philanthropy and civil society through education, research and leadership training.  Located amid the nation's largest concentration of foundations, corporate donors and local, national and international nonprofit organizations, the Center serves as a base for research and ongoing interchange among scholars and practitioners in the field.  The Center's activities are interdisciplinary, with an emphasis on multicultural, women's and international philanthropy.  Within this framework, the Center sponsors seminars, conferences and lectures; fellowships; research projects; and publications.
  
Generous program funding for the 2014 and 2015 International Fellows is provided by the Charles Stewart Mott Foundation with additional support from The Winnipeg Foundation, Metcalf Foundation, University of San Andres, Centro de Estudios de Estado y Sociedad (CEDES), Friends of the Fellows and program alumni from around the globe.

Recruitments of PATH:

PATH is an international, nonprofit organization that currently seeks qualified candidates for one available position in our Ho Chi Minh City office:

Project Director (#6690)to manage and monitor all aspects of a new, 3-year project aimed at reducing hypertension-related morbidity and mortality in Vietnam. Under the guidance, supervision and direction of the Vietnam Program Team Leader, the Project Director will: lead, plan, develop, implement, monitor and evaluate project activities; provide technical assistance to project staff and partners and vision for Vietnam strategy and business development; work with staff and project partners to ensure delivery of project milestones, identify issues/challenges, and develop strategies for effective project implementation; coordinate the Project Steering Committee and Technical Working Group activities; serve as PATH representative to donors, collaborating institutions, and on national working groups and task forces..  
Knowledge, skills and experience required:Advanced degree in medicine, public health or related field; at least 10 years of experience working in public health and a minimum 3 years of program management experience; demonstrated knowledge of health system strengthening and public-private partnerships; experience working with government counterparts at both national and provincial levels, and the private sector; demonstrated report writing and presentation skills; excellent written and spoken Vietnamese and English; willingness and availability to travel within Vietnam up to 30 percent per year; experience in non-communicable disease is a plus.
